body:
That was also 60-70 years ago. I could be wrong but from what I've heard they aligned with the progressive movement of their time. They pretty much just killed anyone they suspected as a threat to the regime, and I think it was mostly that simple. Very similar to what SJWs/Antifa/BLM do now by calling everything "hate speech". Either way, the modern communist movements are almost entirely dominated by SJWs.

Communism is pretty much the radical authoritarian version of the progressive "liberal" movements. The idea that it's not is a lie fabricated by them to claim they aren't authoritarian just like the far-right. Similar to the political compass website plotting leftist politicians as way more libertarian than the right-wing ones, even though that's obviously false. "Authoritarianism is good when I agree with it!".

body:
Not really imo. Both want to take over the world. Fascism usually implements more of a state capitalist economy and is extremely authoritarian positioned on the social right. Communism implements pure socialist economics and is also extremely authoritarian positioned on the social left.

They're definitely different ideologies, albeit being very similar in practice. In the end, all that really matters is that they're both extremely authoritarian.

body:
> whites improve the conditions of the areas we control

It depends. I can think of plenty of examples of both improvements and destruction. How about Stalin, Hitler, Andrew Jackson, FDR, Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton, Mike Pence, Antifa and BLM, most serial killers, hell most of the government?

> jews exist only to trick, exploit, destroy, and leech off their host nations.

You're making too many assumptions based on ethnicity. Even though you see a pattern, even if there *were* a pattern, it's unfair to judge every individual person based entirely on that. Even if we assume that jews and blacks are generally not as good of people as europeans (which I don't believe), it's undeniable that there are still plenty of both jews and blacks who are just as good as famous whites. Guilt by association is a major fallacy and can have serious consequences.

> they aren't capable of creating good music, art, societies, useful inventions, or culture in general

As defined by who? If you like a certain culture that's great, but that doesn't make it objectively better for everyone.

Guilt by association is a major fallacy and can have serious consequences.

the big difference is that whites improve the conditions of the areas we control while they contribute nothing. jews exist only to trick, exploit, destroy, and leech off their host nations.

they aren't capable of creating good music, art, societies, useful inventions, or culture in general. jews bring only negativity and spread it like wildfire. they can try to sell degeneracy and pseudoscience disguised as "liberation" as much as they want, but they're overplaying their hand just like they did in weimar.

you people just won't learn.

body:
Trump being in the same quadrant as libertarians doesn't mean he's a libertarian. He's definitely got a lot of auth tendencies, and is actually closer to most Republicans and some of the Democrats despite being in a different quadrant.

With his media portrayals I'd think of him as more auth too, but if you watch him honestly his real attitude is much different. I'm still not a fan but he's not the monster the news makes him out to be. He's got a point about the fake news. With a few exceptions, he normally isn't trying to force his personal beliefs on people. The Democrats make their whole campaigns on this, so if Trump were plotted as more auth they would have to be too, which would put them at almost the same level as Hitler and Stalin which I don't believe is accurate. Believe me, I was tempted to make him more auth, but I'm also extremely libertarian biased so even Jorgensen seems auth to me.

I'm still not a fan but he's not the monster the news makes him out to be. He's got a point about the fake news. parent.body:
Great compass!

My only issue is that, personally, I would've placed Trump a bit (okay more than a "bit") higher on the Authoritarian axis, because he's not exactly a libertarian, not like Mike Pence either, but I feel like he should be higher up.

And, if I may make a suggestion, I'd say add a progressive/conservative bar and show everybody's positions on there.

edit: word
parent.body_html:
Great compass!

My only issue is that, personally, I would've placed Trump a bit (okay more than a "bit") higher on the Authoritarian axis, because he's not exactly a libertarian, not like Mike Pence either, but I feel like he should be higher up.

And, if I may make a suggestion, I'd say add a progressive/conservative bar and show everybody's positions on there.

edit: word

post.body:
As we know, the 2020 election chart on politicalcompass.org isn't exactly useful:

![](https://i.imgur.com/QeCLeLq.png)

Umm, sorry, but Trump is *not* literally Hitler and neither Trump or Biden are exactly lassiez-faire enthusiasts. And I'm pretty sure Hawkins isn't the most libertarian candidate either.

So I decided to re-make the chart with the goal of having more honest positions for the major candidates:

![](https://i.ruqqus.com/post/3bcx/-daRA6JfQ90)

For the major candidates, we actually have a fairly normal year sparing Biden's dementia. Biden and Harris occupy the more authoritarian positions to the left of the American center. Biden is a bit more authoritarian than most Democrats: he supports all of the normal Democratic ideas, such as banning guns and regulating free speech, but is also found in support of some traditionally conservative positions, such as criminalizing drugs.

Despite constant media polarization, Trump is slightly more libertarian than normal, but otherwise in the average position for a Republican (in 2016 he was further left, but has since shifted rightward). He generally sides with the live and let live approach to Americans' lives. Some decisions, such as the legalization of drugs, he has left to the states. But for someone who also supports the death penalty, waterboarding, doing away with immigration, and regulating free speech with regards to the flag or Israel, he's not exactly anti-authoritarian either. Mike Pence might be more of a cause for concern, as he seems to have "old conservative Democrat" syndrome and very authoritarian tendencies.

Some may be surprised to see Bernie Sanders placed in the lib side of the axis. However, he is not as tightly-knitted as the other Democrats and is willing to think for himself, even as insane as his ideas may be. I will point out that until recently, for example, he opposed gun control legislation. He is certainly an outlier to the party and unlike most of the other candidates. While most Democrats push towards "making a change" and progressive ideals, Bernie's extremism is on the economic axis, not the auth/lib axis (note that any position on the left side of the compass leans towards socialism, which is an extreme position despite encompassing a wide range of ideas).

Jo Jorgensen is a pretty standard libertarian, but a few things shift her more towards the authoritarian side of the compass. She supports legislation banning the confederate flag on public property, overriding states' decisions on the matter and therefore free speech. She also supports expanding anti-discrimination laws which would force religious business owners to act against their beliefs. She has espoused some SJW tendencies on twitter and supported movements such as BLM and Antifa, which is quite interesting for someone with libertarian beliefs. 

Howie Hawkins, the Green and Socialist party candidate, is about where you'd expect economically. He also undoubtedly pushes progressivism, landing him at about the same place as Biden and Harris on the auth axis.
post.body_html:
As we know, the 2020 election chart on politicalcompass.org isn't exactly useful:

Umm, sorry, but Trump is not literally Hitler and neither Trump or Biden are exactly lassiez-faire enthusiasts. And I'm pretty sure Hawkins isn't the most libertarian candidate either.

So I decided to re-make the chart with the goal of having more honest positions for the major candidates:

For the major candidates, we actually have a fairly normal year sparing Biden's dementia. Biden and Harris occupy the more authoritarian positions to the left of the American center. Biden is a bit more authoritarian than most Democrats: he supports all of the normal Democratic ideas, such as banning guns and regulating free speech, but is also found in support of some traditionally conservative positions, such as criminalizing drugs.

Despite constant media polarization, Trump is slightly more libertarian than normal, but otherwise in the average position for a Republican (in 2016 he was further left, but has since shifted rightward). He generally sides with the live and let live approach to Americans' lives. Some decisions, such as the legalization of drugs, he has left to the states. But for someone who also supports the death penalty, waterboarding, doing away with immigration, and regulating free speech with regards to the flag or Israel, he's not exactly anti-authoritarian either. Mike Pence might be more of a cause for concern, as he seems to have "old conservative Democrat" syndrome and very authoritarian tendencies.

Some may be surprised to see Bernie Sanders placed in the lib side of the axis. However, he is not as tightly-knitted as the other Democrats and is willing to think for himself, even as insane as his ideas may be. I will point out that until recently, for example, he opposed gun control legislation. He is certainly an outlier to the party and unlike most of the other candidates. While most Democrats push towards "making a change" and progressive ideals, Bernie's extremism is on the economic axis, not the auth/lib axis (note that any position on the left side of the compass leans towards socialism, which is an extreme position despite encompassing a wide range of ideas).

Jo Jorgensen is a pretty standard libertarian, but a few things shift her more towards the authoritarian side of the compass. She supports legislation banning the confederate flag on public property, overriding states' decisions on the matter and therefore free speech. She also supports expanding anti-discrimination laws which would force religious business owners to act against their beliefs. She has espoused some SJW tendencies on twitter and supported movements such as BLM and Antifa, which is quite interesting for someone with libertarian beliefs.

Howie Hawkins, the Green and Socialist party candidate, is about where you'd expect economically. He also undoubtedly pushes progressivism, landing him at about the same place as Biden and Harris on the auth axis.

body:
There are extremist sects in every religion:

* Islam: Do I even need to explain ISIS and such?
* Atheism: Communist SJW revolutionaries, things like Antifa and BLM that want to organize a totalitarian regime and kill those who disagree (like North Korea)
* Paganism: Italian Fascism, Nazi Germany, and 90% of ancient nations prior to the Middle Ages which were only interested in power and constantly fought each other for absolute rule. They tortured and killed anyone who dared to dissent. They also watched real people be savagely killed, tortured, and abused for show and entertainment.
* Medieval/Renaissance Catholicism: See Paganism
* Renaissance-Period "Christianity": Endless witch hunts, torture, burnings, savage festivals and parades, etc.

What makes you think this is specific to Judaism? It's all human nature.

post.body:
There's a feature that enables you to follow other users, adding their content to your personalized home feed. We've had feedback that this is too "stalky", allowing for easy downvote trolling.

We've added a [user setting](/settings/profile) that allows you to disable your profile subscriptions. This prevents other users from following you, and hides the follower count on your profile.

This should serve as a nice halfway between total publicity and locked down private profile.
post.body_html:
There's a feature that enables you to follow other users, adding their content to your personalized home feed. We've had feedback that this is too "stalky", allowing for easy downvote trolling.

We've added a user setting that allows you to disable your profile subscriptions. This prevents other users from following you, and hides the follower count on your profile.

This should serve as a nice halfway between total publicity and locked down private profile.
post.title: Ruqqus 2.19 Update: Opt out of subscriptions by other users

post.body:
tl;dr: Reputation shouldn’t be universal. Instead, guild treasuries should be able to mint their own rep currencies which can be earned and spent in the Ruqqus marketplaces of ideas. Users and guildmasters should be able to sort, filter, boost & auto-moderate their feeds based on other users’ net worths, and based on the current market value of posts, using whichever currencies they choose to consider valuable - if any.

> Content warning: extremely long

### The problem
The traditional discussion forum is unfit for purpose in the age of information warfare and ideological polarisation. Although Reddit suffered from corrupt admins who would ban communities and parachute sympathetic mods into hostile subs, these are not essential ingredients for a forum takeover - especially on a site like Ruqqus that is committed to neutrality and free speech, which can’t just ban people for being annoying, extremist, or a bit retarded. 

Whatever tweaks to the forum format the Ruqqus devs make, a determined mob could still subvert the culture, driving away the established community. A larger army of sock-puppets and meat-puppets could defeat guild moderators in a war of attrition; burying legitimate content with their votes and flooding posts with derailing comments. Exiled saboteurs could just come back with a new account. Defensively making guilds private or excluded from /all would kill their growth as no-one would stumble upon them any more.

#### Ruqqus is vulnerable
The only thing protecting Ruqqus at present is its relative obscurity: as soon as the site appears on the radars of well organised political extremists, it becomes a numbers game that the old guard is likely to lose.

Even if options are added to allow users to sort & filter based on other users’ reputation, and to allow guildmasters to apply reputation thresholds to users who would join their guilds, requiring a certain amount of rep before users are allowed to make posts or vote on comments; this would still inevitably lead to a site-wide monoculture where a feedback loop would cause one ideology to define what’s reputable and what’s not. Again, the whole system of reputation could be hijacked by outsiders who wish to destroy the community - we’ve already seen this start to happen with incidents of brigading.

#### A universal system of reputation cannot remain neutral
In this day and age, a site using a traditional reddit-like format cannot remain neutral - it will inevitably become a battleground where one viewpoint drives others away. For a site like this to be resilient to invasions and to be a place where multiple ideologies can exist in the same space, we need more than one market for ideas. We need multiple, parallel meme economies.

### The solution: Guild Treasuries
My suggestion is that guilds should be able to mint their own currencies, which are similar to reputation points except they can be passed on from user to user when they upvote a post or a comment (this can take place on any post in any guild - not just where the currency is minted). Just like real fiat currencies, guild currencies have no inherent value and affect nothing unless a user chooses to voluntarily respect the currency by allowing it to affect their filters. Users can adjust each currency’s influence on their feed - so if they’re sick of seeing political posts one day they can just slide their political currency weights down to 0 for a while.

#### Treasure
When voting on a post or comment a user “spends” their currency, and in return they get to claim “ownership” of the post - that is, it becomes their treasure which they can exhibit in their personal treasure trove on their profile page. The value of a user’s treasure is adjusted for inflation and counts towards their net worth. This mechanic is to deter hoarding of currency and so that the system more closely mimics a real economic system. That is: users need to get something in return for their spending.

Ruqqians then become like art collectors who enjoy the prestige of building up a collection of fine memes and notable commentary that they have bought on the open meme market. The user who bid the most on a given post / comment wins ownership of the original piece, while other users who bid less get issued with a lesser “reproduction” that they can exhibit in their treasure trove should they wish to curate a gallery full of Ruqqus’s finest moments, on the cheap.

#### Treasurers
When a guild mints a new currency, the guildmaster designates certain users as “treasurers”. These are users who are trusted by the guild and who publish a manifesto stating the criteria by which they will reward other users, and in doing so they define what the currency represents. Treasurers effectively print money every time they vote, thus devaluing the currency and encouraging Ruqqians to spend their acquired balance sooner rather than later. Treasurer votes are public so that the market can see if they are being faithful to their manifestos, or if they are trying to subvert the market nefariously.

Some possible currencies and manifestos might be:

Zingoleans
- I promise to lavish Zingoleans generously upon any user who proves themselves competent in the martial art of witty insults

Skullpieces
- The +MindBlown mods will reward strangers who dramatically challenge our preconceptions with our guild currency: Skullpieces

Reichsmarks
- I will give Reichsmarks to anyone exposing “coincidences”

Dust
- I will reward those who glorify the dear leader Kim Il Sung with a delicious bag of Dust

Rep
- The original Ruqqus reputation points, converted into an ordinary currency when markets first open

The economies of Ruqqus
With this system established, the site admins could present new users at signup with a list of the major economies of Ruqqus, allowing them to choose a left-leaning experience, a right-leaning one, a frenly one, a combative one, a funny one; etc., they could customise their frontpage by opting into whatever currencies sound appealing; or they could choose none at all: instead enjoying the pure, unfiltered ruqqus experience. 

The different economies would exist in the same space, mostly living-and-letting-live, but still able to come together for healthy debates in neutral guilds - something that’s not possible if different schools of thought all hang out on completely different websites. Something that’s not possible when a site like Reddit, Ruqqus or Voat becomes a monoculture.

#### Market subversion
It’s possible that hoarders and wealthy elites could eventually take control of a given market or even a whole economy, in order to maliciously filter what users get to read, similar to what has happened with Reddit and its admins who deviously control the algorithm. It’s also possible that people could get locked inside an unhealthy filter bubble, like with *<name literally any chat forum or community on the internet today>*. 

The benefit of a system of multiple, parallel meme economies is that users can simply ditch a currency whose market has become corrupt or toxic, by removing it from their filters. This is far less disruptive than users having to ditch an entire website; migrating from site to site like information refugees and watching the same pattern repeat over and over again. Instead, just throw your sack of Zingoleans down a well and start collecting something else instead. You’ll still have your treasure - but all that effort the trolls expended capturing the market will have been for nothing when users notice the shenanigans and all just opt out.

### Things I’m not sure about

- Ability to buy and sell treasure after acquisition. This could allow markets to be suddenly cornered and subverted by someone selling all their treasure at once, and then voting against the currency’s intended purpose. I’m not sure if treasure trading is desirable - but it could be fun from a meme collector point of view.

- Currency trading. This could also be fun, but allowing currencies to be exchanged would effectively mean there is one universal reputation system again and I don’t think it’s a good idea. Instead of using exchange rates to judge the relative values of currencies, this could be measured by comparing the number of users and guilds who are actively using the currencies in their filters.

- Taxation. I think there needs to be a factor which diminishes currency on every trade - otherwise 2 people could just keep voting back-and-forth on each others’ posts, “creating value” from garbage, and maxing out their net worths artificially. Guilds and / or treasuries should probably be able to set e.g. a 10% tax rate which gets returned to the guild or treasury to prevent this. The lower the tax rate the more open to abuse a currency is, but the greater the power the community would have to influence the meaning of the currency.

- Cursed currencies. Say you want to create a currency to mark people as retarded in some way, so you can keep them out of your guild. Your treasury “curses” the retarded user with 1000 Retarderinos. Now the retard has 1000 Rs they can inflict on other, non-retarded users. So perhaps it should be possible for innocent users to return cursed currency to the treasury - pending the treasury’s approval.

Or: perhaps cursed treasuries could set a 100% tax rate so that the retarded user won’t have any Retardinos left to inflict on others. Or, maybe there just shouldn’t be any cursed currencies 🤷🏽‍♂️.

### Summary
While the markets are functioning correctly, the whole site will effectively self-moderate, and guildmasters need only appoint & sack treasurers, and set their guild thresholds. Nothing needs censoring and no-one needs banning. The invisible hand of the meme market takes care of everything.
post.body_html:
tl;dr: Reputation shouldn’t be universal. Instead, guild treasuries should be able to mint their own rep currencies which can be earned and spent in the Ruqqus marketplaces of ideas. Users and guildmasters should be able to sort, filter, boost & auto-moderate their feeds based on other users’ net worths, and based on the current market value of posts, using whichever currencies they choose to consider valuable - if any.

Content warning: extremely long

The problem

The traditional discussion forum is unfit for purpose in the age of information warfare and ideological polarisation. Although Reddit suffered from corrupt admins who would ban communities and parachute sympathetic mods into hostile subs, these are not essential ingredients for a forum takeover - especially on a site like Ruqqus that is committed to neutrality and free speech, which can’t just ban people for being annoying, extremist, or a bit retarded.

Whatever tweaks to the forum format the Ruqqus devs make, a determined mob could still subvert the culture, driving away the established community. A larger army of sock-puppets and meat-puppets could defeat guild moderators in a war of attrition; burying legitimate content with their votes and flooding posts with derailing comments. Exiled saboteurs could just come back with a new account. Defensively making guilds private or excluded from /all would kill their growth as no-one would stumble upon them any more.

Ruqqus is vulnerable

The only thing protecting Ruqqus at present is its relative obscurity: as soon as the site appears on the radars of well organised political extremists, it becomes a numbers game that the old guard is likely to lose.

Even if options are added to allow users to sort & filter based on other users’ reputation, and to allow guildmasters to apply reputation thresholds to users who would join their guilds, requiring a certain amount of rep before users are allowed to make posts or vote on comments; this would still inevitably lead to a site-wide monoculture where a feedback loop would cause one ideology to define what’s reputable and what’s not. Again, the whole system of reputation could be hijacked by outsiders who wish to destroy the community - we’ve already seen this start to happen with incidents of brigading.

A universal system of reputation cannot remain neutral

In this day and age, a site using a traditional reddit-like format cannot remain neutral - it will inevitably become a battleground where one viewpoint drives others away. For a site like this to be resilient to invasions and to be a place where multiple ideologies can exist in the same space, we need more than one market for ideas. We need multiple, parallel meme economies.

The solution: Guild Treasuries

My suggestion is that guilds should be able to mint their own currencies, which are similar to reputation points except they can be passed on from user to user when they upvote a post or a comment (this can take place on any post in any guild - not just where the currency is minted). Just like real fiat currencies, guild currencies have no inherent value and affect nothing unless a user chooses to voluntarily respect the currency by allowing it to affect their filters. Users can adjust each currency’s influence on their feed - so if they’re sick of seeing political posts one day they can just slide their political currency weights down to 0 for a while.

Treasure

When voting on a post or comment a user “spends” their currency, and in return they get to claim “ownership” of the post - that is, it becomes their treasure which they can exhibit in their personal treasure trove on their profile page. The value of a user’s treasure is adjusted for inflation and counts towards their net worth. This mechanic is to deter hoarding of currency and so that the system more closely mimics a real economic system. That is: users need to get something in return for their spending.

Ruqqians then become like art collectors who enjoy the prestige of building up a collection of fine memes and notable commentary that they have bought on the open meme market. The user who bid the most on a given post / comment wins ownership of the original piece, while other users who bid less get issued with a lesser “reproduction” that they can exhibit in their treasure trove should they wish to curate a gallery full of Ruqqus’s finest moments, on the cheap.

Treasurers

When a guild mints a new currency, the guildmaster designates certain users as “treasurers”. These are users who are trusted by the guild and who publish a manifesto stating the criteria by which they will reward other users, and in doing so they define what the currency represents. Treasurers effectively print money every time they vote, thus devaluing the currency and encouraging Ruqqians to spend their acquired balance sooner rather than later. Treasurer votes are public so that the market can see if they are being faithful to their manifestos, or if they are trying to subvert the market nefariously.

Some possible currencies and manifestos might be:

Zingoleans

  • I promise to lavish Zingoleans generously upon any user who proves themselves competent in the martial art of witty insults

Skullpieces

  • The +MindBlown mods will reward strangers who dramatically challenge our preconceptions with our guild currency: Skullpieces

Reichsmarks

  • I will give Reichsmarks to anyone exposing “coincidences”

Dust

  • I will reward those who glorify the dear leader Kim Il Sung with a delicious bag of Dust

Rep

  • The original Ruqqus reputation points, converted into an ordinary currency when markets first open

The economies of Ruqqus With this system established, the site admins could present new users at signup with a list of the major economies of Ruqqus, allowing them to choose a left-leaning experience, a right-leaning one, a frenly one, a combative one, a funny one; etc., they could customise their frontpage by opting into whatever currencies sound appealing; or they could choose none at all: instead enjoying the pure, unfiltered ruqqus experience.

The different economies would exist in the same space, mostly living-and-letting-live, but still able to come together for healthy debates in neutral guilds - something that’s not possible if different schools of thought all hang out on completely different websites. Something that’s not possible when a site like Reddit, Ruqqus or Voat becomes a monoculture.

Market subversion

It’s possible that hoarders and wealthy elites could eventually take control of a given market or even a whole economy, in order to maliciously filter what users get to read, similar to what has happened with Reddit and its admins who deviously control the algorithm. It’s also possible that people could get locked inside an unhealthy filter bubble, like with <name literally any chat forum or community on the internet today>.

The benefit of a system of multiple, parallel meme economies is that users can simply ditch a currency whose market has become corrupt or toxic, by removing it from their filters. This is far less disruptive than users having to ditch an entire website; migrating from site to site like information refugees and watching the same pattern repeat over and over again. Instead, just throw your sack of Zingoleans down a well and start collecting something else instead. You’ll still have your treasure - but all that effort the trolls expended capturing the market will have been for nothing when users notice the shenanigans and all just opt out.

Things I’m not sure about

  • Ability to buy and sell treasure after acquisition. This could allow markets to be suddenly cornered and subverted by someone selling all their treasure at once, and then voting against the currency’s intended purpose. I’m not sure if treasure trading is desirable - but it could be fun from a meme collector point of view.

  • Currency trading. This could also be fun, but allowing currencies to be exchanged would effectively mean there is one universal reputation system again and I don’t think it’s a good idea. Instead of using exchange rates to judge the relative values of currencies, this could be measured by comparing the number of users and guilds who are actively using the currencies in their filters.

  • Taxation. I think there needs to be a factor which diminishes currency on every trade - otherwise 2 people could just keep voting back-and-forth on each others’ posts, “creating value” from garbage, and maxing out their net worths artificially. Guilds and / or treasuries should probably be able to set e.g. a 10% tax rate which gets returned to the guild or treasury to prevent this. The lower the tax rate the more open to abuse a currency is, but the greater the power the community would have to influence the meaning of the currency.

  • Cursed currencies. Say you want to create a currency to mark people as retarded in some way, so you can keep them out of your guild. Your treasury “curses” the retarded user with 1000 Retarderinos. Now the retard has 1000 Rs they can inflict on other, non-retarded users. So perhaps it should be possible for innocent users to return cursed currency to the treasury - pending the treasury’s approval.

Or: perhaps cursed treasuries could set a 100% tax rate so that the retarded user won’t have any Retardinos left to inflict on others. Or, maybe there just shouldn’t be any cursed currencies 🤷🏽‍♂️.

Summary

While the markets are functioning correctly, the whole site will effectively self-moderate, and guildmasters need only appoint & sack treasurers, and set their guild thresholds. Nothing needs censoring and no-one needs banning. The invisible hand of the meme market takes care of everything.
post.title: The solution to brigading, forum takeovers and ideological monocultures: Guild treasuries & parallel meme economies
